message.content: This question requires general knowledge about animals that use light to their advantage. Among the options given, comb jellies are known to use bioluminescence to attract prey and communicate with each other. Dolphins, cats, and whales do not primarily rely on light for their survival and do not have specific adaptations related to using light. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer.

This question requires some basic knowledge about animals and their use of light. Comb jellies, also known as ctenophores, are known to use bioluminescence, a form of light production, to their advantage. They can produce flashes of light to attract prey or to scare off predators. Dolphins, cats, and whales do not typically use light in this way, so they are not the correct answers.

This question requires some understanding of how certain animals use light to their advantage. Comb jellies, also known as ctenophores, have bioluminescent cells that they use for various purposes. They can emit light to attract prey, communicate with each other, and even camouflage themselves. Dolphins, cats, and whales do not use light in the same way as comb jellies do, so options (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect.
